data.title: azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2 - Part Name ".../OpenSSL License.txt" causes tfx create extension build break
data.body:
Question: Consuming "azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2" node library causes a build break when using "tfx create extension" to create azure task.

Would anyone know what I can do fix this?

Example:
tfx extension create --root <path>\_build --output-path <path>\_build --manifests <path>\_build\extension-manifest-bld.json --rev-version
TFS Cross Platform Command Line Interface v0.6.4
Copyright Microsoft Corporation
error: Error: Part Name '<path>/node_modules/azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2/openssl/OpenSSL License.txt' is invalid. Please check the following:
error: 1. No whitespace or any of these characters: #^[]<>?
error: 2. Cannot end with a period.
error: 3. No percent-encoded / or \ characters. Additionally, % must be followed by two hex characters.

All I did was to add the line
    "azure-pipelines-tasks-azure-arm-rest-v2": "^1.0.4",

to my package.json file and I get the build break from tfx.
Thanks for any advice.

data.title: Environment variable substitution failed in Configuration File (docker-compose.yml)
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Task Name**: Azure Web App for Containers Deploy

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines, Ubuntu:16.04
- Agent - Hosted or Private:  Hosted
   
## Issue Description
I have a pipeline with 3 tasks in it
1. Run a Docker-Compose (Command : Build)
2. Run a Docker-Compose (Command : Push)
3. Azure Web App on Container Deploy 

**Task 1 & 2** are linked with a docker-compose.prod.yml file that have variables that get substituted from a environment variable group (linked with the pipeline ofcourse)

**Task 3** in which I have linked the following Configuration File (to be updated/deployed on my multicontainers web service) :- 
Contents of Configuration File 
```
version: '3.7'

services:
  web:
    command: python3 manage.py runserver 0.0.0.0:8000
    image: "${AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY}/${APP1_IMAGE}:${APP1_VERSION}"
    ports:
      - 8000:8000
  app2:
    command: python app.py
    image: "${AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY}/${APP2_IMAGE}:${APP2_VERSION}"
    expose:
      - 8080
    restart: always
```

However, in Task 3 the variables DO NOT get substituted when the Task is performed. Task updates my multicontainer web service config as it is as shown above.

What confuses me that Task 1 and Task 2 are successfully performed i.e. the yml files linked to those DO get variables substituted from same variable group but Task 3 fail to do so before deploying it to web service.

Important to note that:
* All Variables (AZ_CONTAINER_REGISTRY, APP1_IMAGE, APP1_VERSION, APP2_IMAGE, APP2_VERSION) are NOT secret.

data.title: Feature Request: Support Multiple Database Targets in Task SQL Database Deployment

labels.name: environment:triage
labels.description: Issues need to be triage by environment-deployment team

data.body:
This task works great for deploying to a single database.  It would be even more awesome if it could be enhanced to support deploying the same dacpac to multiple databases.  

I understand we could do this now using "Each" loops in YAML or a custom PS task but it would be great if this pre-built task could accept a comma delimited list of DB names - limiting the functionality to deploying to multiple targets on the same server.

Thanks for considering.

data.title: nuget install task should work with any version
data.body:
The nuget install task should work with any version of nuget. It currently doesn't support the latest nuget.

https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.8.0-preview.2/nuget.exe

No one wants to be blocked from accomplishing their work, and I doubt the azure team wants to continuously update this task every time there is a new nuget version, so this should just work.

data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*:  FEATURE

**Enter Task Name**:  `Package and deploy Helm charts`

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?

Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
Private.  Redhat 7.5

## Issue Description

Using Helm 3, it does not seem possible to run a `helm registry login` command in order to login to Azure Container Registry.  The error we get is:

```
2020-09-23T19:30:09.6325304Z [command]/builds/agent1/_tool/helm/3.3.0/x64/linux-amd64/helm registry login $(server) -u $(user) -p $(password)
2020-09-23T19:30:09.6407913Z ##[error]Error: unknown command "registry login" for "helm"
```

HELM_EXPERIMENTAL_OCI=1 is being set.

I see this:  https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/13005

But don't see it as an available task option?

Are we not allowed to use ACR as a chart store for Helm charts?

data.body:

list here (V# not needed):

## Environment

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

[Include task name(s), screenshots and any other relevant details]

Helm 3.3.4 was released this morning and warnings are now being written to the error stream causing the task to fail. I logged an issue with helm here https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/8792, but they recommended that I log an issue with you.

bacongobbler commented 9 minutes ago • 
edited 
Please file an issue upstream with Azure DevOps. There's nothing we can do here. Helm is correctly reporting a security issue that the user should address. It is Azure DevOps that is handling the log output incorrectly.

An alternative option would be to fix the permissions of your kubeconfig file within the devops task. I assume this may also be set up by azure devops, which I would again urge you to file an issue there.

data.title: AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2 - Escaping [ results in [[ after deployment.
data.body:
## Note  
Deploying an ARM template using this extension gives a different result than deploying the ARM template using Powershell or [Azure Portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/#create/Microsoft.Template).

data.title: DotNetCoreCLIV2 push has no ability to skip duplicates
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/DotNetCoreCLIV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted
    
## Issue Description

A pipeline that tries to push a NuGet package can result in a 409 (Conflict) if the pipeline is run again with no change in the version number.

For example, if the following YAML is run more than once (with no project changes), all runs (except the first) result in an error:

```yaml
steps:
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'pack'
    packagesToPack: '**/*.csproj'
    versioningScheme: 'off'

- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  continueOnError: true
  inputs:
    command: 'push'
    packagesToPush: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/*.nupkg'
    nuGetFeedType: 'internal'
    publishVstsFeed: 'XXXXXXXX'
```

> Pushing XXXX.1.0.0.nupkg to 'https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/'...
>   PUT https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/
>   Conflict https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/ 72ms
> To skip already published packages, use the option --skip-duplicate
> error: Response status code does not indicate success: 409 (Conflict - The feed already contains 'XXXX 1.0.0'. (DevOps Activity ID: CCA0F039-7739-4D8A-9B96-BC42DBCCEA1C)).

Per the error message, I need to set `--skip-duplicate`, but there is no way to set it. I tried adding an `arguments` value and inspected the source code, but I don't see any easy solutions.

### Error logs

> Pushing XXXX.1.0.0.nupkg to 'https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/'...
>   PUT https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/
>   Conflict https://XXXX.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/XXXX/nuget/v2/ 72ms
> To skip already published packages, use the option --skip-duplicate
> error: Response status code does not indicate success: 409 (Conflict - The feed already contains 'XXXX 1.0.0'. (DevOps Activity ID: CCA0F039-7739-4D8A-9B96-BC42DBCCEA1C)).

data.title: DownloadPipelineArtifact artifacts size is not precise enough
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadPipelineArtifact@2

## Environment

Azure Pipelines. MSRC-CCF. Agent version: 2.174.2
Agent: Hosted - ubuntu-18.04

## Issue Description

DownloadPipelineArtifact@2 logging includes size of downloaded artifacts. The size is only precise to the `0.1MB` so everything below `0.05MB` (assuming rounded to the closest digit) will be reported as `0.0MB`, which makes it looks like no artifact was effectively downloaded:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42961061/93897013-82c8d200-fce9-11ea-9cae-0dd087ba6ada.png)

Job: https://dev.azure.com/MSRC-CCF/CCF/_build/results?buildId=13022&view=logs&j=e2a2669a-638d-5159-fc94-d9196412c4a4&t=728b2fc9-b164-5bae-57f2-601e07337b91 

Instead, the size should be reported in `B` or `kB` for small artifacts, depending on their size.

data.title: Build fails because of incorrect Build.SourceBranch variable value
data.body:
*Type*: **Bug**

**Enter Task Name**: any task with condition using the `Build.SourceBranch` variable

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines (agent version: '2.174.2', image version: '20200827.1')

## Issue Description

The variable `Build.SourceBranch` is documented to have this format for Git repositories: `Git repo branch: refs/heads/master`. This format was changed in the latest Azure Pipeline build agent so our builds are failing now.

See documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/build/variables?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml

### Task logs

This is the condition we use in the **S3Upload@1** task:

```
- task: S3Upload@1
  condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/development'))
```

Here is the log from the **S3Upload@1** task which shows the format has changed:


```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/development'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('development', 'refs/heads/development'))
Result: False
```

Second task:
```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('development', 'refs/heads/master'))
Result: False
```


### Troubleshooting

This was working with agent version: '2.174.1', image version: '20200827.1'.

Builds from such agents show successful **S3Upload@1** and so the check was working correctly:

```
Starting: S3Upload
==============================================================================
Task         : Amazon S3 Upload
Description  : Upload file and folder content to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (S3) Bucket on AWS
Version      : 1.7.0
...
All uploads to S3 completed
Finishing: S3Upload
```

This log confirms the format of the `Build.SourceBranch` variable:

```
Evaluating: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master'))
Expanded: and(True, eq('refs/heads/development', 'refs/heads/master'))
Result: False
```

data.title: FileTransform correctly applies all transforms but still reports Error Unable to apply transformation for the given package - Changes are already present in the package.
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: bug

**Enter Task Name**: FileTransform

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
      - Account: PromontoryNetwork
      - TeamProject: newco.com
      - Definition: 2
      - Build Number: 0.2.18

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **windows-latest**


## Issue Description

I have a multi-stage YAML pipeline, that has the following Filesystem Transform task defined in a Deployment Job:

```
- task: FileTransform@2
  displayName: 'Apply Release Transforms'
  inputs:
    folderPath: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
    enableXmlTransform: true
    xmlTransformationRules: |
      -transform *.Release.config -xml *.config
      -transform *.$(Environment.Name).config -xml *.config
      -transform config\**\*.Release.config -xml config\**\*.config
      -transform config\**\*.$(Environment.Name).config -xml config\**\*.config
    xmlTargetFiles: |
      web.config
```

We have two configuration files in the root of the application that need at least the Release transform applied (web.config and ApplicationInsights.config) as well as optional environment transforms.
Similarly there are a number of .config files in the config folder, that have optional release and environment transforms.

Looking at the logs and the transformed files, all transforms are being correctly applied to the target files, but we are still getting the following error reported from the task (note that this is not stopping the deployment, but it is creating noise in the reports that makes it look like an error has occurred):

```
##[error]Unable to apply transformation for the given package - Changes are already present in the package.
```

### Task logs

[23.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5261355/23.txt)

data.title: Environment Transforms are not being applied with AzureRmWebAppDeployment in YAML pipelines
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureRmWebAppDeployment

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines?
        
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number:
      - Account: PromontoryNetwork
      - TeamProject: newco.com
      - Definition: 2
      - Build Number: 0.2.7

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: **windows-latest**

## Issue Description

I have a multi-stage YAML pipeline that I'd like to apply config transforms to my web application. The `*.Release.config` transforms are applied correctly, but I'm not seeing the environment transforms (such as `courier.Dev.config` or `web.Prod.config` being applied. The files are included in the deployment package.

The documentation is clearly confused as to the name used, with the [task documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/deploy/azure-rm-web-app-deployment?view=azure-devops#prerequisites-for-the-task) stating:

> The configuration transformations will be run for .Release.config and .{EnvironmentName}.config on the *.config files.

While the [File transforms and variable substitution reference documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/transforms-variable-substitution?view=azure-devops&tabs=Classic#configuration-transform-file-naming-conventions) states:

> XML transformation will be run on the *.config file for transformation configuration files named `*.Release.config` or `*.<stage>.config`

 A sample stage is configured as (with Stage, Environment and Deployment all with the same name):

```
- stage: Dev
  dependsOn: Build
  condition: succeeded()
  jobs:
  - deployment: Dev
    environment: "Dev"
    variables:
    - group: DevDeploy
    strategy:
      runOnce:
        deploy:
          steps:
          - task: ExtractFiles@1
            displayName: 'Extract files'
            inputs:
              archiveFilePatterns: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/$(artifactName)/$(artifactName).zip'
              cleanDestinationFolder: true
              destinationFolder: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
          - task: qetza.replacetokens.replacetokens-task.replacetokens@3
            displayName: 'Replace tokens in **/*.config'
            inputs:
              rootDirectory: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
              targetFiles: '**\*.config'
              tokenPrefix: '#{'
              tokenSuffix: '}'
          - task: AzureRmWebAppDeployment@4
            displayName: 'Deploy Azure App Service'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: $(azureSubConnection)
              appType: webApp
              WebAppName: '$(WebApp)'
              packageForLinux: '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\$(artifactName)\deploy\'
              useWebDeploy: true
              deploymentType: webDeploy
              TakeAppOfflineFlag: false
              RemoveAdditionalFilesFlag: false
              ExcludeFilesFromAppDataFlag: false
              enableXmlTransform: true
              enableXmlVariableSubstitution: true
```

### Task logs

Logs for Dev Deployment attached.
[TaskLogs.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/5255114/TaskLogs.zip)

## Troubleshooting

### Error logs

No errors are thrown.

`    - task: NuGetCommand@2

Looking at the logs Foo.nuspec creates a nupkg with a version like  1.1.0-feature0098.nupkg

Any ideas what is causing this?

data.title: Add traffic weighting to AzureAppServiceManageV0
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Feature
**Enter Task Name**: AzureAppServiceManageV0

## Issue Description

Currently the App Service Manage task supports swapping slots. It would be nice if it also supported configuring the traffic weight between different slots (see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/deploy-staging-slots#route-traffic). Right now to accomplish the same thing you have to use a CLI task and know the appropriate command (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp/traffic-routing?view=azure-cli-latest).

This change would allow for easier handling of advanced deployment strategies like canary deployments.

data.title: AzureCLI@2 task running az webapp create-remote-connection hangs ubuntu agent due to child processes not terminating
data.body:
## Required Information

**Type**: Bug or Feature (?)

**Task Name**: AzureCLI@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted - ubuntu

## Issue Description

AzureCLI@2 and `az webapp create-remote-connection`
 
There appears to be pitfalls in attempting to establish the SSH SCM bridge connection in context of an Azure CLI agent task with obvious solutions not forthcoming.

`az webapp create-remote-connection` in `bash` with either `&` (background task) or in `pwsh/pscore` `Start-Process` will just hang the task waiting for child processes to exit - and unless you're familiar with the agent's underlying process model, you're in for a nightmare ride.

It is not obvious to me how `az webapp ssh` is best used as it doesn't appear to behave the same as just `ssh`. I imagine it is just for opening an interactive shell session ([`webapp ssh`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp?view=azure-cli-latest#az_webapp_ssh)) and the other is just for a background tcp tunnel ([`webapp create-remote-connection`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/webapp?view=azure-cli-latest#az_webapp_create_remote_connection)). 

> Note: Not to be confused with [`remote-connection create`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/ext/webapp/webapp/remote-connection?view=azure-cli-latest) which also lurks in the 'extension reference' documentation.

This is primarily a usability concern - if attempting SSH connections using this tool and with this task (which is reasonable given its purpose), the resulting processes spawned `az` does not appear to sit well with how the task is managing its process groups on the agent. 

Without using `setsid`, or `pgrep`ing for, in this instance, "webapp", you cannot reliably terminate all the spawned processes. The spawned process which hangs the agent appears to possibly be `python3`.

Such issues could be circumvented if, say, [Add task to run bash scripts on App Service slots](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11441) were adopted.

Is it the responsibility of this task to better manage the parent process group, such that it doesn't hang the agent on finalizing the task? 

Is there a recommended approach worth documenting for working with these types of commands in the context of `AzureCLI@2` ? 

Could this task be improved with some task options regarding the process model?

## Troubleshooting
I used the following inline bash script to troubleshoot what was going on, after the calls to `az webapp create-remote-connection`, to query _what jobs and processes were actually running_ at various stages, with the intention of running just a dummy `helloworld.sh` on a target app service (being a custom docker container that has had [SSH enabled as per documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/app-service/configure-custom-container#enable-ssh), and that it has a custom ssh `id_agent.pub` key in its list of `authorized_keys` for `root`, to enable _passwordless_ ssh scripting):

```
shopt
echo Initial processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
curl https://___appservicename___.azurewebsites.net/robots123345.txt
chmod 600 deploy/docker/id_agent
setsid sh -c "az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup___ -p 2222" &
sleep 30s
mkdir ~/.ssh
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
ssh-keyscan -4 -p 2222 -t rsa localhost >> ~/.ssh/known_hosts
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/known_hosts
ssh -T -l root -i deploy/docker/id_agent -p 2222 localhost < deploy/scripts/helloworld.sh
echo Before killing all webapp processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
jobs
jobs -p
kill -- -$(jobs -p)
sleep 10s
echo After kill by PGID webapp processes
ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
jobs
jobs -p
```

## Workaround

Execute the command **`kill -- -$(jobs -p)`** which `SIGTERM`s the processes in the process group of the started background job. 

I also had success with `kill $(pgrep -f webapp)` before I analyzed the process group behaviour and decided to call instead `setsid`. This seems to be the best solution for Powershell Core also as I could not find cmdlets that dealt with process groups.

Others have worked around using [`expect`](https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/issues/3041#issuecomment-559796949).

### Error logs

I hope these error logs may help people trace similar issues they may suffer.

Without the workaround, the task would be stuck at 100%, and never finishing, with the final log entry of note being being either: 

```
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/usr/bin/pwsh'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```

``` 
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/bin/bash'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```

### Task logs

Here is the agent's process stack at various stages:

### Before `create-remote-connection`:
```
   PID   PGID  TPGID S TTY          TIME COMMAND
....
  1407   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:01 /opt/vsts/provisioner/provisioner
  2802   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02  \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Listener run
  2843   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:04      \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Worker spawnclient 116 119
  3400   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00          \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/externals/node/bin/node /home/vsts/work/_tasks/AzureCLI_46e4be58-730b-4389-8a2f-ea10b3e5e815/2.0.16/azureclitask.js
  3460   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00              \_ /bin/bash /home/vsts/work/_temp/azureclitaskscript1600125574374.sh
  3461   1407     -1 R ?        00:00:00                  \_ ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid
```

### After `create-remote-connection` - this is with setsid. Without setsid, the PGID would have been `1407` and there would have been no wrapping `sh` process:
```
   PID   PGID  TPGID S TTY          TIME COMMAND
....
  1407   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02 /opt/vsts/provisioner/provisioner
  2802   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:02  \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Listener run
  2843   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:05      \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/bin/Agent.Worker spawnclient 116 119
  3400   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00          \_ /home/vsts/agents/2.174.1/externals/node/bin/node /home/vsts/work/_tasks/AzureCLI_46e4be58-730b-4389-8a2f-ea10b3e5e815/2.0.16/azureclitask.js
  3460   1407     -1 S ?        00:00:00              \_ /bin/bash /home/vsts/work/_temp/azureclitaskscript1600125574374.sh
  3535   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:00                  \_ sh -c az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3537   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:00                  |   \_ bash /usr/bin/az webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3538   3535     -1 S ?        00:00:01                  |       \_ /opt/az/bin/python3 -Im azure.cli webapp create-remote-connection -n ___appservicename___ -g ___resourcegroup____ -p 2222
  3582   1407     -1 R ?        00:00:00                  \_ ps ax --forest -O pgid,tpgid

data.title: task.setvariable changes variable casing
data.body:
Related: https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/1578

## Description
Azure DevOps sets NPM_CONFIG_CACHE (all uppercase). Some tools like yarn/node, they manage to add a lowercase version of some npm variables (npm_config_cache for example) by directly setting it in an environment block when calling CreateProcess. This breaks some tools when they encounter duplicate variables in their environment block, like msbuild/CL.exe.

I've submitted a fix to the script that sets up the uppercase variable https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/1578 .
To work around the problem in the meantime, I added a task in my pipeline to reset the NPM_CONFIG_CACHE variable and then reset it as npm_config_cache:
Write-Host "##vso[task.setvariable variable=npm_config_cache]$npm_config_cache"

However it seems like ##vso[task.setvariable] always sets the variable in uppercase. This is a problem because it makes it impossible for anyone to work around the duplicate env variable problem.

Area for Triage: Scripting and command line

Question, Bug, or Feature?: Bug


## Expected behavior
task.setvariable does not alter the casing of env variables

## Actual behavior
task.setvariable uses the uppercase version of a variable's name

## Repro steps
```yaml
  - task: PowerShell@2
    displayName: Reset NPM_CONFIG_CACHE
    inputs:
      targetType: "inline"
      script: Write-Host "##vso[task.setvariable variable=lowercase_variable]some value"
  - task: PowerShell@2
    displayName: Display env
    inputs:
      targetType: "inline"
      script:  gci env:* | sort-object name
```

And notice that the variable shown is LOWERCASE_VARIABLE instead of lowercase_variable.

data.title: Feature Request: IIS Web App Deployment deploy to new folder
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroupV0

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Private: Windows 2016 Datacenter, agent v2.174.1

## Feature Description

The "IIS Web App Deploy" task should limit downtime during the deployment by having a feature to extract and transform to a new folder, then update IIS to the new folder. A further option is to not extract/transform if the destination folder already exists.

Benefits:
1) The web site will only be down for the time of an application recycle
2) The previous version is preserved for easy rollback
3) Deploying a previous version will be faster, as extraction and transformation is skipped

*Example* new yaml inputs:

```
- task: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0
  inputs:
    PhysicalPathForApplication: C:\inetpub\wwwroot\$(Build.DefinitionName)\$(Build.BuildNumber)
    SkipExtractionIfPathExists: true
```
```
- task: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup@0
  inputs:
    # Relative to current IIS path
    PhysicalPathForApplication: ..\$(Build.BuildNumber)
    SkipExtractionIfPathExists: true
```

data.title: Allow custom environment name for IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroupV0 XDT transforms
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup

## Issue Description

We have a complex build pipeline that requires us to provide descriptive names for the different stages in order to differentiate between different web projects being deployed side-by-side independent of each other. Because of this, the use of Release.EnvironmentName to get the XML transform files in webdeployment-common-v2/fileTransformationsUtility.ts used by IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup is problematic for us. Right now we're using `##vso[task.setvariable]` to change the value of Release.EnvironmentName in the stages where we use the task, but since Release.* variables are supposed to be read-only, it's only a matter of time before this stops working.

We would like to be able to provide the environment name directly as a parameter to the task and to `fileTransformations()` in webdeployment-common-v2/fileTransformationsUtility.ts, and have it only use Release.EnvironmentName when that parameter is not explicitly set.

data.title: AzureFunctionApp if deploying to a slot with auto-swap which fails, task returns successful
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureFunctionAppV1 

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureFunctionAppV1

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines 

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

When you deploy to a function app `staging` slot that has auto-swap enabled, if that auto swap operation fails, the AzureFunctionAppV1 task either doesn't know or doesn't wait to see if auto-swap was successful and so the task returns green / successful event where a slot-swap failed. This should throw an error and stop the pipeline run if this errors.

## Troubleshooting
- configure a function app with a staging slot that has auto-swap enabled.
- configure the staging slot with the follow app settings based on a function called `healthcheck` that just returns 200:
`-WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_PATH /healthcheck -WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_STATUSES 500'`
The above `WEBSITE_SWAP_WARMUP_PING_STATUSES 500` will force a auto-swap to fail.
- Run a deployment to the `staging` slot using YAML or classic and observe the slots swap fail in Azure Activity Log initiated by the `SlotSwapJobProcessor` and also observe the pipeline task succeed and go green which is should not do.

data.title: Bug: Deployment Job: Stage cross output variable not possible when the deployment job is the first job in the stage.
data.body:
## Bug
```
jobs:
- deployment
  variables:
    octopusVersion: $[ stageDependencies.Build.Build.outputs['SetVersionInformation.OctopusVersion'] ]
```

The output variable from the Build stage can't be used when the deployment job is the first one in the stage. When a different (not deployment) job is running and using the same stageDependency then the deployment can work with the variable.

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines - Executed on On Premis agent.

Only the deployment job is executed on internal agent to contact the deployment platform.
```
Starting: Initialize job
Agent name: '********-Azure-Agent01'
Agent machine name: '**********'
Current agent version: '2.165.0'
Agent running as: '***********'
Prepare build directory.
Set build variables.
Download all required tasks.
Start tracking orphan processes.
Finishing: Initialize job
```

## Issue Description

We have integrated the new functionality to use output variables cross stages. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/release-notes/2020/pipelines/sprint-168-update#jobs-can-access-output-variables-from-previous-stages

The functionality is great and works fine. But during optimisation of the pipeline we refactored and optimised.
- Before stages overview: Build - Package&Deploy (Approval)
- Current stages overview: Build - Package - Deploy (Approval)

With the current setup the "deployment" job is the frist job in the Deploy stage. The tasks in the deployment job need to know the version number that has been build to deploy it. We transfer the variable via a output task variable that is reused in the Package stage and later in the Deploy stage.

But the deployment job is passing the variable from the build stage. Even if the variable is defined on the stage, scoping on the stage. The variable is always empty.

data.title: JSON substitution is case sensitive by default, and also does not log missed keys that match apart from case
data.body:
This is somewhat similar to the issue below, but my point is more of a difference in design opinion than a bug:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/6656

Relevant code to the best of my knowledge, or in the general vicinity:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/a6f349070b6ed807a134974af44e49cf262b8037/Tasks/Common/webdeployment-common-v2/jsonvariablesubstitutionutility.ts#L71

Comment from 6656 that I have found to be true:
'JSON variable substitutions are case-sensitive. Ensure that the casing provided in the variable and appsettings.json are same.'

First, I disagree with this decision as a default.  I can't think of many, if any, cases where I would want to differentiate two json elements by case within the same level.  True, JSON _is_ case sensitive and it does allow for two keys to be differentiated at the same level based on case.  But is this really something a user would ever intend to do?  Perhaps, but probably not.  Which thus leads me to my next point.

If case sensitive vars are unlikely to be intentional, the default should be case insensitive with case sensitive as an override option.  However, this is a breaking change and so on.  If we don't agree here, a log statement would help quite a bit to mitigate this.  "The following pattern was matched, but JSON variable substitution is case sensitive.  Skipping this key."

One could arguably blame the user for making the case mistake, but I would offer the counterpoint that good UX / DX design should strive to match intent of the user and warn them when there may be a mismatch between intent and results.

Thanks,
Travis

data.title: IIS Web App Manage (On machine group) | Adding bindings should be a graceful operation
data.body:
**WHEN** choosing the "Add binding" option in a "IIS web app manage" task
**IF** you have a binding that requires a certificate (https) and you have a thumbprint provided
**THEN** the first initial deployment will succeed
**THEN** all the consecutive ones will fail on the part where netsh is called in a similar manner:
`"netsh" http add sslcert ipport=0.0.0.0:443 certhash=*** appid={a78bae04-5ec5-4fc4-a879-c9fd8ba3ddb0} certstorename=MY`
**BECAUSE** the binding with the given certificate already exists

So currently you have to no if you are deploying a binding initially or not, and customize the deployment and only turn on/enable the add bindings part for the initial one or else it will fail.

I think it would be proper if given the error message _SSL Certificate add failed, Error: 183
Cannot create a file when that file already exists._ we shouldn't fail the task, and continue adding missing bindings if any or with execution of next task, but currently this fails a deployment.

data.title: Documentation: AzureFileCopyV4 output variable documentation incomplete
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

documentation issue

**Enter Task Name**: AzureFileCopyV4  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureFileCopyV4

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
   
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: n/a


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: windows-latest

## Issue Description

The [AzureFileCopyV4](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureFileCopyV4) task has poor documentation on working with its output variables. In v3, the variables outputted were task inputs. In v4, they are created as [output variables](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/variables?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml%2Cbatch#use-output-variables-from-tasks) (and not defined in the task ui). The documentation between v3 and v4 does not change in any way to reflect this.

You have to know to dig into the [task code](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzureFileCopyV4/AzureFileCopy.ps1#L197) to find out that the output variables are titled:

- StorageContainerUri
- StorageContainerSasToken

Following the [output variables](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/variables?view=azure-devops&tabs=yaml%2Cbatch#use-output-variables-from-tasks) documentation, we can then reference the variables like so:

```
- task: AzureFileCopy@4
  inputs:
    SourcePath: 'Readme.md'
    azureSubscription: 'Test'
    Destination: 'AzureBlob'
    storage: 'azdo'
    ContainerName: 'workshops'
    BlobPrefix: ''
  name: AzureFileCopy
- script: | 
    echo $(AzureFileCopy.StorageContainerUri)
    echo $(AzureFileCopy.StorageContainerSasToken)
```

I can submit a PR for the readme update if desired.   Thanks

### Task logs

N/a

## Troubleshooting
n/a

### Error logs

n/a

*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: Azure File Copy  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
Hosted
Image: vs2017-win2016
Agent: Azure Pipelines 5

## Issue Description

I recently upgraded a task the Azure File Copy task from v1 to v4 and noticed a change in behavior. I'm using the task to copy files to an Azure Storage Account. The container that gets created has its 'Public Access Level' attribute set to 'Container' whereas the older version was setting it to 'Private'. The consequence is that anyone having (or guessing) the container URI gets access to the container. Since the task also generates a time-constrained SAS Token, I doubt that anonymous access to the container is really intended.

Digging a little bit in the code, I noticed that the Create-AzureContainer function will set the permission to 'Container' is the storage account is not premium. If it is premium, the default permission ('Private') is used. I don't see a compelling reason to tie security option to the performance characteristics of the Storage Account.
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzureFileCopyV4/AzureUtilityAz1.0.ps1, lines 57-59

To sum it up, my questions are: is it intended to create the blob container with anonymous access by default or is this a bug? Is there a way to change this behavior and the create private containers instead?

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

data.title: AzurePowerShell task - variable links to PS1 files
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzurePowerShell

## Issue Description
I've invested some effort to unify pipelines of several products/repos into a collection of universal scripts. Our pipelines are run on Self-Hosted server, my scripts are stored in specific folder outside agent root. I am going to clone pipelines for individual projects, but the path to my scripts has to be hardcoded. If the path changes, it will have to be updated in all clones as well. The total number is pretty high.

Currently the path can't contain environment variable. Would it be possible to support this? This is my preferred approach. The server runs on Windows so that env. var would have to follow Windows notation %VAR%. For other OSes this should follow their conventions.

I've also tried to create a shortcut in the C.\ folder pointing to PS1 file in different folder hoping this hardcoded path is less likely to break. No, this fails.

Another approach is to specify some organization-wide variable and use in PS1 path. 

Any support for dynamic paths is highly appreciated.

data.title: Docker Build and Push Command has flaky output (sometimes)
data.body:
## Required Information

**Bug**  
*Type*: Build fails. It shouldn't

**Enter Task Name**: Docker v2.170.2

## Environment
- Server: dev.azure.com
- Agent - Self hosted vsts container running in azure aks
- Image: microsoft/vsts-agent:ubuntu-16.04-docker-18.06.1-ce-standard
    
## Issue Description

We recently began receiving a rather meaningless error from a docker - build and push task. Somewhere in the dockerfile, around step 4 or 5, it starts doing node stuff, yarn install, yarn build etc. Theres no evidence in that output that the docker build process even began.

### Task logs
```
Starting: Build and Push Bullclip Web
==============================================================================
Task         : Docker
Description  : Build or push Docker images, login or logout, or run a Docker command
Version      : 2.170.2
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://aka.ms/azpipes-docker-tsg
==============================================================================
##[error]Unhandled: Failed find: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat '/vsts/agent/_work/2/s/node_modules/@babel/plugin-proposal-async-generator-functions/node_modules/@babel/plugin-syntax-async-generators/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/.bin/json5'
Finishing: Build and Push Bullclip Web
```

I was able to build other pipelines with docker files (that nothing had nothing to do with node) at the time. I finally logged into the vsts container and ran `docker prune` (we still had 14gb of free space). After that the build began to work... I can't really confirm that that was the fix for it as I wasn't out of space.

Whatever the underlying problem was the output I got from the task was really baffling (still is) and is not actionable. If the error occurred in the docker build process i should see docker build output. If the docker environment was broken i should see an appropriate message. Instead I got a ENOENT seemingly in relation to some node operation.

There isn't even the `/usr/local/bin/docker build -f /vsts/agent/_work/3/s/Dockerfile ...` line.

data.title: Command-line task reports false success if STDIO left open
data.body:
_Originally posted by @glucaci in https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11334#issuecomment-583333300_

I've created new issue because nobody answers on closed one.
Below is the content of the original post:

### Original:
Lately we have the same problem with a .NET Core Task. I reported this also in https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-image-generation/issues/1386 because I'm not sure where this fits.
```
Starting: dotnet tool restore
==============================================================================
Task         : .NET Core
Description  : Build, test, package, or publish a dotnet application, or run a custom dotnet command
Version      : 2.164.0
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/dotnet-core-cli
==============================================================================
/opt/hostedtoolcache/dotnet/dotnet tool restore --ignore-failed-sources --no-cache --verbosity normal

... restoring packages

Restore was successful.
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/opt/hostedtoolcache/dotnet/dotnet'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```
and the task will remain blocked until build timeout expires.

### Update:
Also with Task Version 2.169.1

#### Workaround:
Enable ```Continue on error``` and set ```Timeout``` on 1 min

       - darrell.tunnell@uniun.io
       - https://dev.azure.com/uniun/Uniun
       - release: https://dev.azure.com/uniun/Uniun/_releaseProgress?_a=release-environment-logs&releaseId=767&environmentId=1456

- Agent - Hosted

       - windows latest:
> Agent name: 'Hosted Agent'
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7790423Z Agent machine name: 'WIN-IP8NBLIKQOR'
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7790754Z Current agent version: '2.168.2'
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7809491Z Current image version: '20200517.1'
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7815809Z Agent running as: 'VssAdministrator'
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7824139Z Prepare release directory.
2020-05-21T09:44:22.7830742Z ReleaseId=767, TeamProjectId=6334dd50-2591-41b3-8764-746de9f071eb, ReleaseDefinitionName=Uniun Website


## Issue Description

Task Info:

> 2020-05-21T09:44:25.0695397Z ==============================================================================
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0696201Z Task         : Azure Web App for Containers
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0696794Z Description  : Deploy containers to Azure App Service
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0697175Z Version      : 1.163.5
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0697674Z Author       : Microsoft Corporation
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0698253Z Help         : https://aka.ms/azurewebappcontainertroubleshooting
2020-05-21T09:44:25.0698727Z ==============================================================================

**Problem**:
I am seeing my release pipeline fail during deployment, when executing this task.
However the error log looks odd, because it is trying to get authorization to a scope name, with a variable in the scope name: `$(env_resource_group)` and failing - and that variable happens to be one that used to be a variable in my pipeline (but is not any longer). 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3176632/82550753-f3eb5380-9b56-11ea-90a0-cb8b1370014d.png)

If I look at the yaml view of this task on the release pipeline - this shows the values I am executing it with:

```
variables:
  docker_registry_name: 'labdocker.azurecr.io'
  docker_image_repository_name: 'uniun/uniun'
  semver: '$(Build.BuildNumber)'

steps:
- task: AzureWebAppContainer@1
  displayName: 'Deploy docker image'
  inputs:
    azureSubscription: 'ARM Staging'
    appName: 'uniun-staging'
    containers: '$(docker_registry_name)/$(docker_image_repository_name):$(semver)'
```

So I am unsure as to why it still fails trying to access a scope with variable "$(env_resource_group)" reported in the scope name, which is ofcourse invalid.

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

- If i run the release with `system.debug` true variable, do I need to sanitise the log output before upload here?

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

FYI This link had a lot of stuff which only related to yaml pipelines and was hard to tell how to do this for classic release pipelines, but I did eventually find mention of `system.debug` variable, but not sure how to sanitise logs. Would be great if there was a dedicated link for each scenario.

### Error logs

[Insert error from the logs here for a quick overview]

data.title: Allow overriding existing files in ExtractFiles task.
data.body:
This change adds an optional input to override existing files when using the ExtractFiles task. The input will default to true as that is likely what the user wants. This will change the default behavior of the task.

[Related PR 1](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/6760)
[Related PR 2](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/11594)
[Related Issue 1](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11082)
[Related Issue 2](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11593)

data.title: AzureAppServiceSettings@1 should not continue until the app service has restarted
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: AzureAppServiceSettings  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
Azure Pipelines

    

    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
org: restonmtc, proj: serverless openhack, build: serverless openhack s2, 20200511.1

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

Hosted agent: vs2017-win2016

## Issue Description

When you set an app setting, it (in my case) causes the app service to restart, however, the task completes at the beginning of the restart, causing the next task -- deploying the code package, to fail.  Putting a time wait seems to be the only way to get it to work, but the time is variable, so this is very problematic -- and not documented at all.

data.title: Resync keys of Azure workspace returns error “504 Gateway Time-out”
data.body:
I ran resync keys for my active directory Azure workspace. I followed the instructions given at the following links:

(using Try It) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/azureml/workspacesandcomputes/workspaces/resynckeys#code-try-0

and

(Using Azure Bash) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/how-to-change-storage-access-key#code-try-2

But both the cases I got a response code "504 Gateway Time-out" (I have replaced the actual workspace name resource group name and sub id below for security purpose.)

Code:

ms@Azure:~$ az ml workspace sync-keys -w -g ProjectSystemException: Message: { "error_details": "\r\n504 Gateway Time-out\r\n\r\n

504 Gateway Time-out
\r\n


Can somebody tell what is going wrong here and how to proceed? (Note: I need to run resync keys to connect Azure devOps to Azure portal through service connection)

data.title: Azure App Service Deploy: missing copying node_modules folder when the agent is Ubuntu
data.body:
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Azure App Service Deploy  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Background

I have an Azure DevOps Release pipeline, with 2 stages, Development/Test.

Same set of tasks, only difference is Agent Specification. 
* Development: ubuntu-18:04
* Test: windows-2019

**npm Task version: 1.***
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5653381/80341308-4f0e8b00-88b6-11ea-98f0-ca0b47bb309e.png)
Here what I am doing is, ontop of the build artifact, I am doing **npm install express**. Note: in the artifact folder there is no package.json.

**Azure App Service deploy Task version: 4.***
Deploying to Web App on Linux
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5653381/80341319-546bd580-88b6-11ea-8e59-304c8648a79f.png)
Now I am deploying the modified artifact (which will contain **node_modules** folder installed from npm task)

## Issue Description

The issue is, when the agent is **ubuntu-18:04**, when the release is completed, the node_modules folder is not present when I explored in the App Service. When I change the agent to **windows-2019**, it's getting copied.

data.title: DotNetCoreCLIV2:Restore - User level NuGet.config not loaded
data.body:
## Required Information
*Type*: bug 
**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2 (v2.131.0)

## Environment
- Server -  TFS on-premises 2018.U2
- Agent - Private: 
  - Agent.OS | Windows_NT (Server 2012R2)
  - Agent.OSVersion | 6.3.9600
  - Agent.Version | 2.131.0

## Issue Description
Using `Destination directory` aka `--packages` cmdline option break user Nuget.config loading. 
Our agent run under a service account with an Nuget.config in `%appdata%\NuGet\NuGet.Config` containing multiple packageSources + packageSourceCredentials + apiKey. Projects don't have any project-level settings. 

When settings the `Destination directory`, with an empty temp. nuget config, the nuget config. don't get loaded at first sight. 

When removing this settings, it works.

### Task logs
#### When using  `Destination directory`
[logs_TargetBuildDirectory-EmptySelectedFeed.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/4484920/logs_TargetBuildDirectory-EmptySelectedFeed.zip)
#### When not using `Destination directory`
[logs_NoTargetBuildDirectory-EmptySelectedFeed.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/4484921/logs_NoTargetBuildDirectory-EmptySelectedFeed.zip)

data.title: Unable to set secure file to download based on pipeline variables
data.body:
## Required Information

- **Type**: Bug
- **Task Name**: DownloadSecureFile  

## Environment

- **Server**: Azure Pipelines
- **Agent**: Hosted

## Issue Description

We'd like to store credentials for different environments in different secure files. For example, we might have:

- `creds-a.env`
- `creds-b.env`
- `creds-c.env`

Based on the context of the current YAML pipeline, we can determine whether we're deploying to `a`, `b`, or `c`. It's important to note that we don't have this at the very start of the pipeline and it's not something we can hardcode or ask for; it's a runtime evaluation.

I'll put some pseudocode here, but the pipeline looks sort of like:

```yaml
- task: Bash@3
  inputs:
    targetType: inline
    script: |
      # Figure out the target environment, then write a variable for later use.
      echo "##vso[task.setvariable variable=target;]a"
- task: DownloadSecureFile@1
   name: credentials
   inputs:
     secureFile: creds-$(target).env
```

Unfortunately, it [appears `DownloadSecureFile` runs before the job](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/91ed11388bfa1462fd999a7849c3c8b5db08eccb/Tasks/DownloadSecureFileV1/task.json#L50) which means we can't affect the filename by running analysis in the pipeline like this.

It's not obvious that a job placed explicitly at a particular location in the pipeline is going to try to do work before the point at which it appears; and it seems like a defect that we're unable to use secure files in a more flexible way.

data.title: The "File Transformation Task" needs to be renamed to include "And Pipeline Variable Substitution"
data.body:
I just spent several hours of time trying to figure out how the resulting deployed web.config file for an application is getting a value for a connection string that is not specified in the web.config, the web.<thatenvironment>.config, or any other file in the project. 

It was only after copying the build definition json to a text editor and searching did I find that there was a pipeline variable that was the potential source, but it took a while longer (more reading) to realize that while the "File Transformation Task" does perform that intended service, it does something else - replaces content in those files with pipeline variables. 

* The naming for the task is misleading in one of the worst ways - an unrelated or nonsense name that does not describe the functionality of the task would be a safer choice than the one it has now that very specifically describes only half of the total functionality (and you cant even opt out of the unsaid half)
* The documentation is slightly misleading as it does not mention that the variables its discussing are pipeline variables until a teeny little blue "Note" after the examples.  
* The log messages that are emitted reinforce that like its name implies, this task is yet another XDT task. It doesnt state what variables its using or what values, or that its even using pipeline variables and not environment or other variables.

data.title: publishTestResults doesn't publish test results for dotnet vstest
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug-ish

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLI

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: qktech, QK Kiosk, QK Kiosk, 20200311.3

- Agent - Hosted or Private: Hosted
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: windows-latest 

## Issue Description

`publishTestResults` is [documented](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/dotnet-core-cli?view=azure-devops) as follows:

> Enabling this option will generate a test results TRX file in `$(Agent.TempDirectory)` and results will be published to the server. This option appends `--logger trx --results-directory $(Agent.TempDirectory)` to the command line arguments.

It does not do this for all commands except `test`. It will do nothing in the example below.

```
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'custom'
    projects: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/drop/xxx/xxx.dll'
    custom: 'vstest'
    publishTestResults: true
```

`dotnet vstest` supports at least `--logger` [as per its documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-vstest) and the second example suggests it supports `--ResultsDirectory` (albeit not `--results-directory`).

I would appreciate if DotNetCoreCLI (i) understood `vstest` as a command but at least (ii) understand it's invoking `vstest` and set the command line flags appropriately, if `publishTestResults` is true.

### Task logs

```
##[debug]exec tool: C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe
##[debug]arguments:
##[debug]   vstest
##[debug]   D:\a\1\drop\xxx\xxx.dll
"C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" vstest D:\a\1\drop\xxx\xxx.dll
```

data.title: Help migrating yaml build and classic release pipelines to multi-stage yaml.
data.body:
I'm looking at migrating my old CI/ CD pipelines which are a mixture of the new YAML pipelines for builds and the 'classic' UI-based Releases pipelines into a multi-stage, environment-based YAML file, but I'm struggling to find the docs/ examples that follow along with what we are currently doing.

There are usually three environments: `Test`, `UAT` and `Production`.

They're all AKS based and at the moment the build that creates the docker container(s) will, as part of it's output, store a `DeployService.yml` file that's used by the release pipeline to update each environment (by modifying the image tag, and some environment variables) prior to running `kubectl apply -f DeployService.yml`.

Currently I've got several projects that follow this pattern:

| Name | Purpose | Type | Description |
|--|--|--|--|
| `{project-name}.ci.yml` | CI build | YAML-based | Triggered on pull-requests. Builds, run tests, etc. The only output is test results and success/ failure in Azure DevOps. |
| `{project-name}.cd.yml` | CD build | YAML-based | Builds the output upon successful PR into master. This is more often than not a docker container. |
| `{project-name} - Release` | Release Pipeline | 'Classic' UI | Release pipeline, triggered by `{project-name}.cd.yml` success and deploys into the `Test` environment. From there it's promotion to `UAT` and `Production`. |

I'd like to move them all to the newer mult-stage YAML build and release pipeline using a single file.

As it stands, I've created a new yaml file by using the new pipeline template and then copying and pasting bits of my existing CD builds.

At at the moment the new build can:

* Do a build that creates and pushes the docker container.
* Trigger the release that pushes into the `Test` environment.

As part of this, the template created a `manifests` folder in the repo that contains a `deployment.yml` and a `service.yml`. It also created an environment which connected to our `Test` AKS cluster.

So my questions are these:

1. Given the `deployment.yml` needs to contain environment specific variables (think `ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT`), how do I provide those additional environment specific variables per-release environment?
2. Can I re-create the same promotion-style release pipeline that I had using the Classic UI releases?
3. Will the CI build fit into this process at all? Or should I leave it in a separate file?
4. Given there are lots of projects that follow this pattern, and for the most part they all do the same thing but build project specific containers, is there any reusability available between repos?

data.title: Xcode@5 Code Signing Error when building a project with embedded framework that does not support manual signing
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug
**Task Name**: Xcode@5  

## Environment

All

## Issue Description

`Xcode@5` fails to build an Xcode project that has multiple targets that have mixed signing needs, resulting in a Code Signing Error with this format:

```
<Framework> does not support provisioning profiles. <Framework> does not support provisioning profiles, but provisioning profile <Provisioning Profile Name> has been manually specified. Set the provisioning profile value to "Automatic" in the build settings editor.
```

In my case, I am trying to build an Xcode project produced by Unity 2019.3, which includes a new `UnityFramework` that does not support manual code signing.

According to the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2019.3/Documentation/Manual/StructureOfXcodeProject.html), a new set of command line arguments for `xcodebuild` are to be used to target manual code signing to the main `Unity-iPhone` target only, and leave `UnityFramework` to be able to signed automatically.

Using `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_APP` and `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER_APP` instead of `PROVISIONING_PROFILE` and `PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER` in the `xcodebuild` command fixes this issue.

Adding a "Custom Provisioning Profile Argument Suffix" parameter to `Xcode` under the Signing action would allow this issue to be fixed. See [this blob post](https://lyricsboy.github.io/2016/11/30/xcode-8-automatic-signing-ci/) for more information about how the suffixes are used in building Xcode projects with multiple targets.

Here is a Unity produced Xcode project that can be used to demonstrate the issue:

https://content-infrastructure-uploadbucket-iuhbmg0o97e6.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/AzureXcodeCodeSignError.zip

You can attempt to build it using a command similar to this:

```
/usr/bin/xcodebuild -sdk iphoneos13.2 -configuration Release -project ./Unity-iPhone.xcodeproj -scheme Unity-iPhone archive CODE_SIGN_STYLE=Manual CODE_SIGN_IDENTITY="<Code Sign Identity>" PROVISIONING_PROFILE_APP="<Provisioning Profile UUID>" PROVISIONING_PROFILE_SPECIFIER_APP="<Provisioning Profile Name>"
```

data.title: Consider adding authorization on SQL server using Service Connection
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

In my organization we're using Dacpac to create not only database structure but also map SQL users with AAD groups. As such operations can be [performed only with AAD accounts](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sql-database/sql-database-aad-authentication-configure?tabs=azure-powershell#create-contained-database-users-in-your-database-mapped-to-azure-ad-identities), we're looking for an option to make our CD pipeline task to authorize on Azure SQL server using an AD account. For a number of reasons putting account password to variables or setting up an own agent and using 'Active Directory - Integrated' auth method are not viable for us.

My suggestion would be to leverage /AccessToken feature of SQLPackage and extent SqlAzureDacpacDeployment task with ability to authenticate on target SQL server as service principal used in Azure Devops service connection.

This should be relatively simple using methods ADAL as shown in [this example](https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/stefan_stranger/2018/06/06/connect-to-azure-sql-database-by-obtaining-a-token-from-azure-active-directory-aad/)
The same, of course, can be done in a custom Powershell script ran in AzurePowershell task, but in such case it would be required to pass service principal password to the script as a variable, which is a considerable security weakening compared to obtaining the password inside the task using Get-VstsEndpoint

data.title: Self signed certificate in certificate chain error - Variable Group - Azure Key Vault
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*:  Question

**Enter Task Name**: Azure Key Vault  


## Environment
- Server - **Azure Pipelines** or TFS on-premises?
    
    **- If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number:** 

> 1.  Have pushed the same credentials to a cloud system during a build pipeline to test; no errors.
>  2.  Current issue is using a release pipeline and pushing credentials by same method to private agent; error received.


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

    **- If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version:** 

> Microsoft Windows Server 2019 Datacenter
> agent v2.160.1 (commit 8c04bd1)


## Issue Description

The company utilises SSL inspection on its networks. We run the self-hosted agent with a certificate using the generated Powershell from Azure DevOps plus the additional parameter **"--sslcacert cacert.pem"** following the advice from (1), specifically the section titled **"Work with SSL client certificate"**.


A release pipeline is used to make a number of Secrets from an Azure Key Vault available through a linked variable group, scope set to entire release.


While running the release pipeline the Azure Key Vault task fails due to an error:
`Self signed certificate in certificate chain`
The Key Vault task cannot be configured to continue on error.

**Note:** Instances of the task DownloadBuildArtficats honour the sslcacert setting and function as expected.


This behaviour has been mentioned before on **MicrosoftDocs** (2), and also in **azure-pipelines-agent** (3).


**Question:** Is it fair to assume that the Key Vault task requires all the benefits offered by enciphered data transfer, and is why self-signed certificates are not recognised as this could potentially compromise the data?


(1) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/agents/certificate?view=azure-devops-2019

(2) https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/5501

(3) https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-agent/issues/1820

Currently unable to provide, too much data to sanitise.

data.title: Index Sources & Publish Symbols fails with TF400813: Resource not available for anonymous access. Client authentication required.

labels.name: regression
labels.description: This used to work, but a change in the service/tasks broke it.

data.body:
## Required Information

**Type**: **Bug**
**Enter Task Name**: **Index Sources & Publish Symbols**

## Environment
- Server - TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 17.143.28912.1

- Agent - Private
    
    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 


Capability name | Capability value
-- | --
Agent.OS | Windows_NT
Agent.OSVersion | 10.0.14393
Agent.Version | 2.131.0


## Issue Description

Running the task results in the described error. Looking at the task code, the following execution flow emerges:

1. The code reaches https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/c5de8d6beb30280eae54e6f0c2a17bb59ad98d92/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1#L175-L177 and discovers that there is no account name, no PAT and Aad is not used. 
1. So, the code executes https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/c5de8d6beb30280eae54e6f0c2a17bb59ad98d92/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1#L19-L20, sending an unauthenticated request to the on-premises Azure DevOps server.

This is strange. I would expect it at least to pass `-UseDefaultCredentials`. As it is now, the request is aborted, which is totally expected.

In effect, it makes it impossible to publish symbols to the on premises Azure DevOps server.

### Task logs

[log_6_588891.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/3655069/log_6_588891.zip)


### Error logs

`TF400813: Resource not available for anonymous access. Client authentication required. - Azure DevOps Server`

data.title: Azure SQL DacpacTask v1.0 ignores DoNotDropObjectTypes
data.body:
*Type*: Question, possibly a bug

**Enter Task Name**: Azure SQL DacpacTask  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted 

## Issue Description

I have two Azure SQL servers/databases, one of which acts as a Dev db (the source) and another a Test db (the target). The database in target is currently identical to that in the source, including login and user identifiers. I have extracted a DACPAC file from the source. I have a simple build pipeline which adds the DACPAC file into deployment artifact. Then I have a simple release pipeline which is set as follows:

A single hosted agent job with vs2017-win2016 spec, pulls up the artifact from the build
The agent job includes a single task Azure SQL DacpacTask, v1.0, which
uses ARM connection type
successfully working azure subscription registration
fully qualified URI for Azure db (the target)
correct db name
SQL login "int119"
password pulling from an existing Azure key vault linked to a variable group
Deploy type SQL DACPAC file
action Publish
DACPAC path pointing to the file in the artifact
blank Publish profile
Additional SQL arguments set as follows: /p:DropObjectsNotInSource=TRUE /p:DoNotDropObjectTypes=Users;Logins;RoleMembership;Permissions;Credentials;DatabaseScopedCredentials /tt:1800 /p:CommandTimeout=1800 /p:TreatVerificationErrorsAsWarnings=TRUE
Firewall set to autodetect
Control options enabled
No output variables defined

data.title: Azure SQL DacPac deployment failing when trying to drop a column even though /p:BlockOnPossibleDataLoss=false is set for SqlPackage.exe
data.body:
Hi, my release in Azure DevOps fails when trying to deploy a dacpac saying:

"The column [dbo].[table_Name].[bRowVersion] is being dropped, data loss could occur."

I have already set the parameter to SqlPackage.exe to ignore this behavior. Also, why is this showing up as a warning and still being treated like an error, blocking the deployment.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5325072/63556620-e170c900-c588-11e9-9f60-1b70cee32c46.png)
